data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
ros_msgs_plugin: keep shared ptr of sub-msg in parent scope

Description of old erronous behavior:
When a sub-message is added (through calling get-field on a parent
message), we add it to the list of sub-messages of the parent
(sub_messages_ map).

If we delete a sub-message before the parent message, it goes out of
scope and we did not delet the respective entries in the list of
sub-messages of the parent.

When a new message is created that gets the same address as the deleted
sub-message, the parent message will clean it up thinking it is the
sub-message.

Fix: Just store the shared pointers in the list of sub-messges so they
actually do not go out of scope until the parent message is deleted.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
cx_protobuf_plugin: add option to use linked protobuf messages

protobuf message registers either work through lookup of linked messages
in the shared library or through reading proto files directly.

The latter was already supported through cx_protobuf_plugin, the former
requires to link the compiled proto definitions into the plugin, which
does not directly work.

Instead, offer a cmake macro that generates plugin based on
an existing shared library or proto sources and the cx_protobuf_plugin.

This allows to use the generated plugin instead of the cx_protobuf_plugin for
usage with lookups from the linked messages.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
cx_ros_msgs_plugin: remove recursive mutex by reducing locked scopes

The issue that was solved by recursive mutexes could also be solved by
just releasing the relevant lock before modification of the fact base.

The actual issue is now documented more generally in the cx_plugin as it
seems to be a very easy-to-be-made pitfall.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann

By properly installing the target library, the location is available in
the installation environment.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
cx_ros_msgs_plugin: protect maps and default initialization

As multiple threads could be writing to the hash maps, one recursive
mutex serves as a safety mechanism.

The "recursive" part is necessary for situations, when functions such as
ros-msgs-get-field are called from a LHS of a rule, which therefore get
evaluated e.g., when the subscription callback asserts a fact in the
environment.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
project: complete overhaul of clips core structure

Remove the intertwined lifecycle node triangle of cx_clips
cx_clips_executive and cx_feature_manager.

Instead, follow a lean structure of having a single liefecycle node that
manages environments and has a cx_feature_manager object as member.

cx_clips_executive is broken down into individual features.

This also reworks the parameter retrieval for clips features to be more
natural (no need to specify types).

Also, this eliminates the need for explicit clips-sided startup
coordination.
Instead, startup is done entirely through the lifecycle node through the
order and types of loaded clips plugins.

Lastly, actually make every feature capable of being applied to multiple
environments and clean up multi-environment management in general.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
skill_execution_feature: do not automatically cancel old skills

This behavior caused major issues due to the asynchronous nature of
feedback given by the executors.
This manifested in locking issues when attempting to use the CLIPS
environment within a SkillExecutionMaster while unlocking.
THe calls were stuck indefinitly (not sure why, I initially suspected
due to cleanup of the ExecutionMaster object during execution, but never
properly followed up on this).

Instead, simply fail attempts to start new actions while the
corresponding executor is already running.

The cases of cancelling old skills can be handled from within clips.

data.message:
cx_clips: simplify debug configs

1. Remove the debug level as multi-layered debugging is handled through ROS
anyways and the functionalities were not used anyways.
2. Centrally manage watch level through config instead of having the
   cx_clips_executive set the watch level.
3. Make logging to file configurable
4. Change log file name to executive_<time-date> format.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
cx_clips_executive: major overhaul of configurations

Simplify the configuration of the CLIPS-Executive by:
1. getting rid of specs and spec management.
   This is not needed as users can simply create multiple yaml files
2. make configuration files configurable.
   The CLIPS-Executive now accepts parameters
   'clips_executive_config' and 'clips_features_manager_config'.
   The default for the former is a file in
   agent_dir/params/clips_executive.yaml.
   The default for the latter is the whatever the value of the former
   is.
3. reworking the initialization stages of the CLIPS-Executive.
   There are no multi-stage initializations anymore.
   Instead, first the config for the features is fetched in order to
   request initialization of all mentioned features.
   Then, the CLIPS-Executive internal file loading is handled.
   Finally, the user files are loaded. There is no need to explicitly
   separate this in stages, as the loading is sequential in nature
   anyways.
4. remove clips-dirs variables. They are not needed as now the dirs are
   always both the cx_clips_executive dir as well as the agent_dir.
   If users want more dirs, they can configure them from within CLIPS.
5. rename all variables to kebab to camel case.
6. changed API to load configs from clips, now specify the file (full
   path). Path substitutions @CX_DIR@ and @AGENT_DIR@ are available for
   convenience.

data.author: Tarik Viehmann
data.message:
cx_msgs: rework some Skill msgs

SkillExecutionerInformation msgs are only published, noone listens to
them. Hence we might as well remove them.
SkillActionExecinfo is slightly renamed to fit the pascal casestructure.
Also, information to call skills should contain both the robot number
(renamed from agent_id ro robot_id) as well as the information about the
executor that should take care of them.
That way one can easily map actions to executors and buld central
solutions that control multiple robots by having multiple executors of
the same kind running, each for a diferent robot.

data.message:
cx: fix time and CLIPS loop

ROS2 uses a unix time based time format represented by a double. Fawkes
used a tuple for representation consisting of time in seconds and a
second entry for milliseconds. To keep everything consistent with ROS2,
the timing functions were changed and some mutex bugs in the main loop
were fixed.

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_skills: add skill execution mechanism

Possible to implement a given skill using the
SkillExecution class as a base class and writing
the execution logic inside perform_execution.

SkillExecutionMaster controlls the execution:
request, cancellation, confirmation. It is used
by the skill execution feature, so the clips env
can start a skill execution by providing the master
with the corresponding information about the skill.

Both Master and SkillExecution publish/are subbed to the
same topic - /skill_board and answer on different request types.

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_blackboard: implement blackboard and reader/writers classes

- The blackboard class allows the opening of interfaces
either to writing/reading using services. It also holds an
instance of the interface manager.

- InterfaceReader is also template based class, which provides
functions such as open_reading, reading, enqueuing msgs, updating
readers, when a writer updates an interface. This class should be
used/inherited from, when wanting to have a blabkcoard reader

- InterfaceWriter is similar to InterfaceReader but for writing
instances

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_blackboard: implement InterfaceNode and Manager

- InterfaceNode will be a template based ros2 node, which will
create the corresponding interface and allow other nodes to write/
read from it using services
- InterfaceManager will provide the creation of interface nodes,
as well as setting general information for the corresponding node.

InterfaceNode is a template class, expecting the interface service
message for communication as well as the actual interface message.
The ros2 generated messages/services do not have a base class, so
dynamic polymorphism is not suitable.
Therefore, the manager holds a map of the possible interface node
types, which are saved inside an std::variant and for casting inside
std::optional.

Drawback: each interface must be included inside the manager and the
corresponding casting must be provided
-> hardcode to some degree

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_msgs: create interface messages for PddlGenInterface

The format for creating an interface will be:
1) define message with the interface name
that holds the data
2) create *interface_name+Messages message that will
represent all possible messages for an interface
3) populate 2) by creating individual messages
4) create services that will be used inside the
blackboard for communication (read/write and so on)

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_clips_executive: initial version of the clips_executive

The current implementation is fetures independent, except for
config-, and redefine_warning_feature.
The CX is a lifecycle node, which registers a clips env
executive and at start maps actions, path-substitutions and
spec name based on the clips_executive yaml file.
As it is clips-based, after activation it refreshes and runs the
clips-agenda in a timer_callback.
The main building blocks are the clips files.
The fawkes test-scenario is almost integrated in the context of
the ros cx, other than the pddl-parser and skiller.

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_features: create config feature

This features mimic the functionallity of the
fawkes config features. It depends on the yaml-cpp
library to parse and iterate through the yaml config
file. As yaml-cpp does not provide Scalar types,
I've implemented such YAML namespace functionallity.
There are also recursive functions that allow the
iteration trough the whole file, while adding
the corresponding confval to CLIPS.

The feature provides a config-load function to the
Clips Env to extract the configuration values of a
given config prefix.

All Config files will be saved under:
cx_bringup/params/*

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_lifecycle_manager: add lifecycle nodes controller

This package will serve the role of a controller for
the running lifecycle nodes as recommended by the docs.
Each lc node gets assigned a client instance, which
will be a client for the services get_state and change_state
and implement the request to those services.

The manager will then create the corresponding clients
and start an initialisation script to configure and activate
the specified lc_nodes from the launch file.
Furthermore, the manager will implement  disable/pause/resume fncs
for the lc_nodes.

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_features: load registered features as plugins in Manager

The FeatureManager utilises the pluginlib functionallity
and loads the features, which are registered as plugins
inside the cx_features package.
Each new feature needs to inherit from the cx:ClipsFeature class
and be registered as a plugin in the cpp and added as a library in the
cmake file.
Then, each feature should be added to the cx_bringup params file with
the appropriate fields. This will ensure it's loading by the Manager.

cx_features: add FeatureManager and MockFeature

This commit includes the alpha-version implementation
of the Features manager.
It's functionallity will be to save instance of all
the registered features (later as part of laucn/params).

It will be called from the ClipsEnvManager via the two
available services to either call the clips context
initialisation/destruction of the requested feature.
The FeatureManager will then call the corresponding feature
function and send feedback to the manager.

Also a MockFeature inheriting from the ClipsFeature
interface is included, which will be then used for a
simple unit test.

data.author: Ivaylo Doychev
data.message:
cx_clips: first version of ClipsManager and Client

This is fairly big commit, including the first
full implementation version of the ClipsEnvManager
and Client for the manager.

The Manager is mainly based on the Fawkes-ClipsEnvManager
implemented by -  Tim Niuemuller [www.niemuller.de]

The manager is implemented as a Lifecycle Node so it's
behavior can easily be controlled.
Main differences: functions to interact with the manager
are implemented as ROS2 services. Currently:
- clips_manager/create_env
- clips_manager/destroy_env
- clips_manager/add_clips_features
- clips_manager/assert_can_remove_features
- clips_manager/remove_features

The interaction with the ClipsEnvManager happens through
the ClipsEnvaManagerClient, who can be seen as wrapper
(API). It creates client to all the availabe services
from the manager.
This way, other nodes/plugins/packages can communicate with
the Manager through it's client and thus won't need to always
implement client services and/or have a local instance of it,
as the manager is fairly huge.

In order to initialise/destroy the context of the underlying
feature, the manager will communicate with a running node in
the face of the ClipsFeaturesManager, which will interact with the
registered Features.
